messageBody:
One thing you have to understand is that when a assertion failed, the method is exited because an Error is thrown. There is no way to avoid this unless you write your own JUnit app. I don't think that it's what you want...

if you have 3 mendatory fields, you write 4 methods. The first 3 test that you successfully see when fields are missing and the 4th to see if everything's fine when you have your 3 mendatory fields. You have done quite the same thing (removing one field after another) but my approach is more simple.

Remember: "keep tests simple". The more complicated the test code is, the more likely you introduce errors in the test code. The goal of unit testing is not to debug your test code :-)

to implement the simpliest tests possible:

- use the setUp() method to create your data object
- create 4 tests methods (in my example it's 4)
- remove one single mendatory field at the beginning of each test method
- call the fail() method to tell JUnit that something wrong happend

private Data data;

public void setUp () {
data = new Data();
data.put(...);
}

public void testField1Missing () {
data.remove(...);
try {
profile = home.create(data);
} catch (IllegalFieldsFormatException e) {
// if home throws this excpetion when a field is missing, it's fine
}
}

public void testAllFieldsOK () {
try {
profile = home.create(data);
} catch (IllegalFieldsFormatException e) {
fail("this execption should not have been thrown")
}
}

Hope it helps

-Vladimir
